awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Food as a Defining Cultural Factor
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists are curious about what ancient people ate and drank. Archaeologists at the University of Florida are investigating the foods and beverages consumed by the ancient Maya, by analyzing organic chemical residues and starch grains in pottery vessels and on stone grinding tools. These analyses are innovative in that they help identify ancient Maya "recipes" rather than single ingredients. They provide insights into the individual's choices of ingredients and methods of combining, processing, and serving foods and drinks, using different tools and vessels. This study is focused on periods of cultural transition, to better understand the relationship between people and food during times of social and environmental change. Differences in Maya recipes through time, across space, and among community members enable understanding of the relationships among people, their foods, and their environmental and social circumstances. The role of food in culture is vital to understanding expressions of personal identity and responses to changing social and environmental circumstances. Thus, this study is relevant to understanding of human cultures in all places and at all times, including today. This study incorporates several methodological advancements by: 1) conducting residue analysis on museum-curated and recently recovered archaeological artifacts to assess preservation and recovery techniques, 2) adding new chemical and micro-botanical signatures to the array of expected ancient Maya ingredients, and 3) using methods to elucidate food combinations and processing steps rather than just ingredients. These approaches are influencing many scientific disciplines, and fostering collaboration among archaeologists, geochemists, and analytical chemists. This research has an important educational component, because multiple graduate students are learning how to collect, extract and prepare organic chemical residues and starch grains from archaeological contexts for analysis.
        
This study will use recovered food residues to identify combinations of ingredients found on food-related artifacts from several pre-contact Maya sites in Belize and Guatemala. The focus is on times of Maya cultural transition, both early (300 BC-250 AD) and late (800-1100 AD), and on places in different ecological zones (coastal, inland, and riverine). Techniques used include liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry, gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, and starch grain analysis by microscopy. This is the first research project in the Maya region to identify the chaine operatoire (operational sequence) of Maya "recipes" using residue analysis and to explore correlations between food ingredients and food-related artifacts and activities at different stages of food production and consumption. Residues will be correlated to style and inferred function of the artifacts (determined by analysts working on multiple archaeological projects), and the context in which they were found (site location, age, function, and social status), to provide insights into the relations among foods, food-related tools and vessels, and the people who used them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The NSF-funded project Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Using Residue Analysis to Explore Ancient Maya Recipes and Food-Processing Technology (NSF-BCS DDRI #1836554, PI Emery, co-PI Duffy) analyzed residues on the surfaces of food-related artifacts from Maya archaeological sites using chemical (liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry or LC-MS) and physical (microscopic starch grain) analyses to understand what was eaten and by whom in ancient Maya communities. Rather than focusing on single ingredients or ritual artifacts, we took an untargeted metabolomic approach to identify the widest possible range of residues from a variety of artifacts including grinding stones and pottery storage, cooking, and serving vessels from different contexts, time periods, and sites. Our goal was to explore ancient Maya recipes including ingredients and preparation methods, and to understand variations through time and space, and between different community members. Studies of ancient foodways such as this one provide important cultural information because what we eat very often reflects our affiliations and beliefs. The foodways of the ancient Maya are particularly important because the Maya were able to survive and thrive, feeding large populations even during times of environmental and political stress, and carrying through time into modern day many of the same favorite foods and recipes, an indication of their remarkable cultural resilience. 

For this study, a total of 127 food-related artifacts from seven pre-contact ancient Maya sites in Belize and Guatemala were sampled and analyzed. These sites represent different environmental and geographic locations so we could evaluate whether recipe ingredients reflected local resources or broad cultural tastes. We selected artifacts from two cultural periods reflecting periods of social and environmental stress to see if recipes varied over time, particularly during times of great change. We tested artifacts excavated from different social contexts (such as elite versus commoner and domestic versus ritual contexts) to provide detailed information about the relationship between recipes used by different people in the communities. We also tested artifacts that had just been excavated and those that had been curated in museums for many years. 

The study revealed exciting new information about Maya recipes and the people who made and consumed them. Starches were not well preserved and provided evidence of only a few common ingredients such as corn and chili peppers, but the patterns of their damage did reveal important evidence of various food preparation methods such as grinding and boiling. Remarkably however, chemical residues were recovered from all the artifacts tested and provided fascinating detail on Maya recipes. Chemical residues were recovered from all contexts, and in all time periods and sites tested. They were also recovered from both field tested and museum curated artifacts, clearly proving that artifacts from museum collections can be valuable sources of residues even if they have been washed and stored for many years. Furthermore, most artifact residues contained many different chemical compounds, suggesting complex recipes and/or multiple uses of the artifacts. The metabolomic LC-MS approach revealed a broad range of potential ingredients, and some combinations of residues may indeed represent recipes. For example, the frequent combination of chemical compounds identifying cacao (theobromine and theophylline) together with those indicating tobacco (nicotine and cotinine) and chili pepper (capsaicin), suggests a spicy chocolate recipe with stimulant properties.

We also learned new facts about how foods were prepared and served. Cacao, previously suggested as primarily a drink, was not restricted to drinking vessels, but was present on multiple vessel types, including bowls, dishes, and flat plates, showing that cacao was also part of solid food recipes. Cacao was also present on grinding stones in combination with maize, chili peppers, flavorings, and bioactive compounds (medicinal or stimulant) suggesting that these tools were used for grinding multiple ingredients, and not just maize as is often assumed. Finally, our work provided important insights on who consumed what and when. There were some variations suggesting local tastes and ingredient availability, but many ingredients were similar across all locations and time periods indicating deep ?Maya? food traditions. Fascinatingly, we found cacao residues widely across the different sites and regions and in all artifact types, indicating that cacao was not restricted to use by elite residents or in sacred settings, as has often been presumed.

Overall, the approaches used in this project successfully recovered and identified residues from many artifact types including museum curated specimens, and revealed a wide diversity of ingredients including some already known such as cacao, chili pepper, tobacco, and maize, but many as yet unreported including flavorings and bioactive ingredients. Most importantly, it revealed remarkable consistency between the recipes used by elite and commoner residents, in daily and special foods, and across regions and time periods. 

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2022
Modified by: Katherine F Emery
